sect1.title: The Islands
sect1.para: Dal-Kon is a volcanic archipelago with about 70% of its total land, most of which mountainous, covered with woodlands and forest plantations. Within the relatively small area of its land, Dal-Kon has three climates - temperate, alpine and sub-tropical, and in most of is regions it has four distinctive seasons. Temperate regions, which occupy most of its land, and also sub-tropical regions, enjoy relatively warm temperatures and sufficient precipitation to enable a great variety of agriculture even though rice is the primary food crop.

sect1.title: The Surrounding Seas
sect1.para: The Seas are uniformly warm and life abounds. The reefs are treacherous and the shoals sharply limit the paths of approach for boats. Despite this fishing and kelp gathering are very common ways of making a living all along the seacoast.

chapter.title: Flora and Fauna
chapter.para: The Dal-Kon soil is incredibly fertile. This seems to be a direct side effect of the runoff from various volcanoes. It is especially good for rice and mulberry bushes as well as a variety of fruit trees (Cherry, pear, apple, and plum).

sect1.title: Flora
sect1.para: Silk culture makes up the majority of the exportable goods that leave Dal-Kon. Cultivating the mulberry and the silk worms are considered to be a woman's domain.

Dal-Kon grows a variety of woods from near scrub plants such as Bamboo, and Painted Fern to the majestic Cedar and Red Greatwood. From Bamboo and Cedar to Mulberry and Cherry the woods of Dal-Kon are varied and used for the majority of all building and other construction.
Seaweeds and Kelp abound in the coastal waters. Many of these are gathered for food as well as medicinal purposes.
Dal-Kon has many types of fruit trees. Dalk-Kon dami plums are soft and juicy, with flesh that ranges from tart to sweet. These large, round plums are best eaten fresh, and not for drying.
Dalk-Kon cherry plum have small, tart fruit, and are used for making jams, jellies, and preserves. These plums are cold hardy and will survive in cool storage bins for the winter
Dal-Kon of the Bonsai Tomo grow plums as a favored Bonsai in an open vase form (the middle of the tree has no central leader), in an informal fan-trained shape, or in pyramidal shapes.

Red Dawnwood is a large-growing deciduous conifer with fern-like foliage that contrasts beautifully with its deep red wood. It is an excellent choice for providing shade, as well as beauty. Ultimate size is 80-120 feet with 40 feet at 20 years

Bald Cypress grows naturally in swamps and bogs but the tree can thrive in any soil condition. Its smooth red bark contrasts beautifully with its light-green, thread-like foliage. Ultimate size is up to 100 feet with 35 feet at 20 years
Kitayama sugi or red cedar takes the soaring temperatures of a Dal-Kon seaside summer in stride. This large evergreen is blue foliaged and fast growing. Ultimate size: Up to 50 feet Growth rate

River Birch is a large-growing tree that will grow in all conditions - and its ornamental peeling bark. The tree is found naturally in flood plains, but will also flourish in dry soil. Ultimate size: 75 feet; 40 feet at 20 years

Sugar Maple has deep green summer foliage that turns vibrant orange and red in autumn. It is revered for its hard woods and in the more temperate hill regions, for its maple syrup. Ultimate size: 80 feet; 30 feet at 20 years

batatas or cinnamon vine is a vine that grows up to 10' A vigorous, long-lived twining vine. Much cultivated in Dal-Kon for the large, edible, tuberous roots. The roots are said to remain edible and mild-flavored even when they reach a large size. The small flowers, which appear in summer, are cinnamon scented. Also bears small aerial tubers in the leaf axils. These are edible and can be planted to start new plants.

Wild yam's appearance is distinctive in that the leaves grow in whorls of four or more at each node along the vine's lower length. Toward the top, the number of leaves decreases to one or two per node.

Juncus Rush. Found mostly in temperate regions, typically occurring on moist or wet soil. ht 2-3' . The Juncus provides a soft rush; This common plant of wetlands is leafless, with round, hollow, green stems. Somewhat similar, in overall appearance, to a large, evergreen chives plant with stiff, slender leaves. The stems are used to weave tatami, the traditional floor covering of Dal-Kon homes.

Bamboo. Grasses with perennial, woody stems and, almost always, evergreen leaves. max ht 20' max culm dia 1" The young shoots are of good quality for eating, and the culms are sturdy and useful for stakes, staves, furniture, and other purposes.

Thorned Cherry. Only found on &tisland, the Thorned Cherry is a fruit tree with a gorgeous bloom (purple, red, white and pink blossoms) bearing a delicious fruit. The fruit is , unfortunately, very difficult to harvest for being stuck by the thorns of the tree can cause sickness, hallucinations and even madness.

sect1.title: Fauna
sect1.para: Fish
The Dal-Kon coastal waters are surrounded by coral reefs. Coral is used as an ornamental material and as a polishing agent.
Ivory is found both from the sea in the form of walrus tusk and from the land in the form of Ontabe horn. Ontabe are a large horned rabbit like creature that uses its horn for digging roots.

The Dal-Kon coastal waters abound in fish and shells. Ama (Women divers of the Ama Tomo) search for abalone deep on the ocean floor. (Dal-Kon abalone almost inhabit on the rocks of the seabed, not on the kelp bed). It's very dangerous works, so Ama wear a special amulet called Seman Doman that protects them from peril.

Dal-Kon abalones can grow up to 8 inches long and are often covered with worm growths. The outside of the shell is thin and greyish-brown. The blue and green inner shell is covered with an iridescent (a pearl-like shine or luster) mother of pearl layer.

The abalone itself is eaten as a prized seafood. The shells of abalone provide mother of pearl for decorations. Especially prized are the Imperial island black abalone that provide a glowing white mother of pearl used in decorating sword racks with cherry blossoms.

The viscera of abalone can harbor a poisonous substance which causes a burning, stinging, prickling and itching over the entire body. It does not manifest itself until exposure to sunlight - if eaten outdoors in sunlight, symptoms occur quickly and suddenly. Skin lesions may occur on body parts exposed to the sunlight. It is believed the poison may come from seaweed ingested by the abalone.

Glitter Quills from a puffer fish. Several types of puffer fish in Dal-Kon waters provide the Dal-Kon with hollow but flexible needle tipped tubes that are used to inject medicine as well as serving as the basis of decorative beadwork.

sect2.title: Cosmology
sect2.para: Genesis starts from Chaos. The gods come later (i.e. subject to the rules of the universe)

Of old, Heaven and Earth were not yet separated, and the In and Yo not yet divided. They formed a chaotic mass like an egg which was of obscurely defined limits and contained germs. The purer and clearer part was thinly drawn out, and formed Heaven, while the heavier and grosser element settled down and became Earth. The finer element easily became a united body, but the consolidation of the heavy and gross element was accomplished with difficulty. Heaven was therefore formed first, and Earth was established subsequently.

After the creation of Heaven and earth, Divine Beings were produced between them. Hence it is said that when the world began to be created, the soil of which lands were composed floated about in a manner which might be compared to the floating of a fish sporting on the surface of the water.

There is a natural order or Li. An offence against that natural order causes spiritual distractions or taints known as pollution. Offence and pollution are inseparable ideas. Pollutions are taints that much be removed before man or woman can resume their full role in the life of the community. Death, Birth, sex, disease or causing wounds can all result in such pollution.
Certain offences such as murder, assault, rape, incest, bestiality all leave a stain that must be ritually expatiated and carry also the need of restitution for the offended individual.

The permission of the Samurai to cut down those that stand inthe ways of their duties is pragmatic, as it brings the causing of death from a ritual process and restitution to a normal cleansing on the part of the Samurai.

chapter.title: Shinto
chapter.para: The Way of the Gods, also Kannagara: "the way of the kami ."

sect1.title: Beliefs
sect1.para: All Shinto cults believe in kami, which generally refers to the "divine." Individual clans (uji ), which were simultaneously political, military, and religious units, worshipped a single kami in particular which was regarded as the founder or principal ancestor of the clan. As a clan spread out, it took its worship of a particular kami with it; should a clan conquer another clan, the defeated clan was subsumed into the worship of the victorious clan's kami . What the kami consists of is hard to pin down. Kami first of all refers to the gods of heaven, earth, and the underworld, of whom the most important are creator gods. But kami also are all those things that have divinity in them to some degree: the ghosts of ancestors, living human beings, particular regions or villages, animals, plants, landscape-in fact, most of creation, anything that might be considered wondrous, magnificent, or affecting human life. This meant that the Dal-Kon feel themselves to be under the control not only of the clan's principal kami, but by an innumerable crowd of ancestors, spiritual beings, and divine natural forces. As an example of the potential for divinity: there is a story of an emperor who, while travelling in a rainstorm encountered a cat on a porch that waved a greeting to him. Intrigued by this extraordinary phenomenon, the emperor dismounted and approached the porch. As soon as he reached the porch, a bolt of lightning crashed down on the spot his horse was standing and killed it instantly. From that point on, cats were, in Shinto, worshipped as beneficent and protective kami; if you walk into a Dal-Kon restaurant, you are sure to find a porcelain statue of the waving cat which protects the establishment from harm.
Shintoists believe that the trees of the forest have souls, known as kodama, and that the Kodama-Kami protect the more exalted of them.

There are Shinto shrines where huge trees hundreds of years old are encircled with shimenawa, straw "belts" that designate them as sacred objects. Each tree represents purity and a divine persona, which explains why its wood is revered even after the tree has fallen. In this regard, the unadorned trunks of trees, which have had little more than the bark removed, may be used in shrine architecture and festivals.
Carrying a handful of soil from one part of the island to the tree is an established custom among worshippers.

All Shinto involves some sort of shrine worship, the most important is the Izumo Shrine on the coast of the Dal-Kon Sea. These shrines are often a piece of unpolluted land surrounded by trees (himorogi ) or a piece of unpolluted ground surrounded by stones (iwasaka ). Shinto shrines are usually a single room (or miniature room), raised from the ground, with objects placed inside. One worships the kami inside the shrine. Outside the shrine is placed a wash-basin, called a torii , where one cleans one's hands and sometimes one's face before entering the shrine. This procedure of washing, called the misogi , is one of the principal rituals of Shinto, which also included prayer and spells. One worships a Shinto shrine by "attending" it, that is, devoting oneself to the object worshipped, and by giving offerings to it: anything from vegetables to great riches. Shinto prayer (Norito ) is based on koto-dama , the belief that spoken words have a spiritual power; if spoken correctly, the Norito would bring about favorable results.

sect1.title: Practices
sect1.para: The practices of Shinto are normally performed by the worshippers themselves or by Gakusho (spirit priests) in someones name. Thus there is a large body of common practices that a farmer would in a year without any intervention on the part of an intermediary.

sect2.title: Sangaku or Offering Tablets
sect2.para: The custom of hanging tablets at shrines was established in Dal-Kon centuries before sangaku came into existence. Shintoism is populated by "eight hundred myriads of spirits," the kami. Because the kami, it was said, love horses, those worshipers who could not present a living horse as an offering to the shrine might instead give a likeness drawn on wood. As a result, many tablets dating from the founding of Dal-Kon depict horses.
The tablets seem to be distributed fairly uniformly throughout Dal-Kon, in both rural and urban districts, with about twice as many found in Shinto shrines as in Sohei or Deitic temples.

Recently, devotees of math, evidently samurai, merchants and some farmers , would solve a wide variety of geometry problems, inscribe their efforts in delicately colored wooden tablets and hang the works under the roofs of religious buildings. These sangaku are often acts of homage--a thanks to a guiding spirit--or in some communitities they have been brazen challenges to other worshipers: Solve this one if you can! For the most part, sangaku deal with ordinary Euclidean geometry. Circles and ellipses play a prominent role: circles within ellipses, ellipses within circles. Some of the exercises are quite simple and others are nearly impossible.

Most of the sangaku contain more than one theorem and are frequently brightly colored. The proof of the theorem is usually not given, only the result. Other information typically includes the name of the presenter and the date. Not all the problems deal solely with geometry.

chapter.title: Class Structure
chapter.para: From the outside it would appear that Dal-Kon's society is compartmentalised into four distinct classes by birth: the Samurai (shi), farmers (no), artisans (ko), and merchants (sho). The reality is far more complex. It is true that that is indeed the general ordering of status among the people engaged in those tasks. Careers are hereditary though there is some natural mobility up and down groupings of careers. Acclaim can raise the status of someone (especially in a martial class) up to that of Samurai. A child's life choice may be changed by a marriage contract that gives over the daughter or , more rarely, the son to the new family.

There are those that gain mobility by being spirit called to a craft or class other than they were born to. It is rare but it does happen (usually several times in a generation per village). Thus a son born to an Ashigaru father may become a Samurai by acclaim, or by Kami-kan. A son born to a dyer may be able to become a potter with Kami-kan or contract among the families involved.

There are some life choices that wash away most issues of birth class. The Judges pick and choose those that become Judges, Gakusho, and Shukenja without regard to class, only ability. Only the Judges evaluate those that believe they are Kami-Kan.

sect1.title: Womens Roles
sect1.para: Samurai women are expected to exhibit loyalty, bravery, and take on the duty of revenge. As her warrior husband is often absent, the samurai wife also has important duties at home. Her responsibility is the food and all the household supplies. She oversaw the harvesting of crops, managed all the servants, and takes over all financial business. In matters which concerned the well-being of the family, her advice is sought and her opinions respected. On her, too, fell the burden of providing the proper education of her children. She is to instill in them a strong sense of loyalty to the samurai ideals of courage and physical strength.
All brokered marriages are done through the Samurai women with the exact roles taken in the negotiation dependent on the status of the nearest living female relative.

In wartime Samurai women have to defend their homes. Trained in weaponry, women carry a dagger in their sleeves or sashes and can throw with deadly aim. The naginata, a long, curved polearm, is considered the weapon most suitable for women. All Samurai girls learn the art of naginatajutsu

Sometimes Saumrai women have joined their men in battle, fighting alongside them or directing the troops. Like their husbands, women are expected to commit suicide if the family is dishonored in any way. Some Samurai women use suicide as a form of protest against injustice, as in the case of one woman who killed herself when her husband mistreated her.
Most Dal-Kon traditions and styles of family life have women in a much more subservient role. Unlike the male children have a household, the female rarely has any say about who or when she marries.

There are a few traditions that give women some openings for self destinatiuon. Some Tomo are mother/daughter concerns only and have some protection for the choices they make from within their craft. Geisha, Ama, and Weavers are a few exmples.

sect1.title: The Emperor
sect1.para: His word is law.His speaking is distributed in several ways.

Mi-Kyo-Sho or letters of Advice about policies. These are general statements of goals that ministers and agents use as guidelines for resolving disputes about turf and tactics. Typically conceived by the Emperor, crafted by the Emperor's Judges, and Sealed by the Emperor.
Kudashi-Bumi or letters of instruction. These are the explicit commands that ministers issue to their agents descrivbing what should be done.

Miyo- or Letters In His Voice. These are letters that the Emperor signs for his agents giving them power to resolve or investigate an issue. A similar concept is the "Power of His Hand" carried by the Kaishakunin

sect1.title: Land Grants: Han, Shoen and Shiki
sect1.para: More or less autonomous, the shoen is under the rule of person (kon-ke) or organiztion (ryo-ke). A Kon-ke may be a Daimyo in whose land the Sho resides or another noble born. A ryo-ke is often a great temple. Their interest is in the keeping of their agent residing in the sho. Under these agents are arranged the various tenures of land and the classes of people who hold them.

Associated with each sho is a series of "profit rights" or shares called shiki. A shiki of land is a separate right or profit derivable from it that is vested in a person --- after whom it is named; as, for instance: the Kon-ke-shiki, tenant-shiki, or the like.

Sho-tenures. There are three tenures that are recognized in Dal-Kon for land. There are free tenures of possession which have been derived from the first cultivation of the soil, or from purchase or other modes of out-right acquisition, and which can therefore be bequeathed or disposed of at will, the Kon-ke or Ryo-ke exercising little interference with them. These include outright sale to other Kon-ke or Ryo-ke.

When, however, the holder of a free land gives up the title over it to the Kon-ke or Ryo-ke for the purpose of protection or immunity, a second class of tenure results - that of the commended land. Here the Kon-ke becomes the titular owner, but is in fact normally merely entitled to certain dues from the land, for the commendor usually remains as its possessor and user, and continues to dispose of it as he pleases. Though of course, in general the shoen is typically commended to the Han's Daimyo.

The third class of tenure comprises shiki that have been granted either by the seignior or by the proprietor and are usually hereditary but presumably at least at the beginning inalienable without permission

A rice tax is levied on the produce of the paddies, and a head tax is levied on adult males or adult females of all female Tomo. The rice tax is low (about 3 percent of the crop), but the head tax, payable in handicrafts such as silk and hemp can impose a significant burden. Moreover, the transport of the goods from the provinces to the capital is the responsibility of the taxed, which involves an enormous labour for those living in distant parts.
Adult males are also obliged to give military service and to provide labour for public works at the command of the local Daimyo or Imperial Agent, amounting to not more than 60 days per year.

sect1.title: Guilds (Tomos)
sect1.para: The Dal-Kon maintain a complicated set of craft and other guilds called Tomo. The Tomo exist at Imperial grant and cover all the crafts of Dal-Kon. Membership in Tomo are father/son or Mother/Daughter relations.

Ritualists, Armorers, Ricefield Workers, Weavers, Potters, Scribes, Interpreters, Reciters, Grooms, Husbanders, Ironworkers, Smiths, Bowyers, Fletchers, Brewers, Acrobats, Fishers, Amas, Geisha, etc.. And in some cases the tomo may be more general such as "Quiver Bearers" or military support groups for a specific clan.

Most are born into a tomo, some are contracted into a tomo, and a few are Kami-Kan (spirit called). Typically a ritualist will handle the once a year ritual for each Tomo that inducts a son/daughter into the Tomo. A Judge will be preent if there is a question of Kami-Kan.

Geisha are one of the few Tomo that habitually learn the skills and crafts of other tomos with contracts being negotiated often. Geisha especially have close ties with the ritualists and musical instrument tomos.

sect1.title: Sohei
sect1.para: The Sohei are warrior monks. Monastic orders of martial practitioners who at one time rivaled the Judges and Inner Clans for power. Many Sohei form the basis of a martial tradition and may act as the trainers for a specific clan. Some Sohei owe alleigience to a clan.

Some few Sohei live in more isolated locales for the pursuit of mental disciplines and mystical powers. Such Sohei are know as Yamabushi or Hijiri. Literally a "Mountain Monk". Said to posses a great deal of mystical powers against the supernatural due to they're extreme ascetic lifestyle. They practiced the art of SHUGENDO to attain supernatural powers.
It is said that the Judges maintain a Sohei monastary in the Imperial Island

sect1.title: Gakusho
sect1.para: By nature, Shinto is focused on purification and the living, but Shinto Priests must also act as a buffer between the living and the Kami or deities that protect mankind and also demand tribute or become angered. Also, not all Kami are helpful to man and must mere be placated into not showing anger.
Most Gakusho are male but a few (about 10%) are female.

The Gakusho wield a varied set of powers and abilities. Some of the Gakusho become masters of Tantric or Mantric magic. Based on Shingon or "True Word" it acts most often as a soul shaping craft magic. It is typically constrained to being used on the gakusho themself except when healing is required. These are simply called the Shingon.

In addition the Gakusho act as assesors of the Karmic debt that one has accumulated, able to see the threads of the past life as they affect the present and future. In some circumstances they can intervene to alter or lessen the debt. Those who are skilled in this are called Karmic Masters.

The Dal-Kon language is said to hold power in it's very structure. Some Gakusho have becoime Masters of the Power of Words, or the craft of Kotodama. Not quite true magic in that he must say verses or write down the words of power. nonetheless, he or she has the ability to bend the very fabric or reality. This works on all creation - not just supernaturals but humans as well. These are called the Kotodama Masters.

Some temples shelter blind wise women known as Miko. Miko hold the ability of Powerful Prognostication. They can tell a client the day they will die and why if the client is brave enough. They often come into they're power at puberty but must remain 'pure' to be at they're most powerful. In they're youth they channel Spirits of the Dead and Kami and wield a great deal of power. They go blind in they're 40's as a result but live to be very old. Some say because they see things no mortal is meant to see.

Suminagashi-literally, "spilled ink" or "ink-floating"-is a Dal-Kon technique for creating free-form marbled patterns on paper or similar surfaces. sect1.title: Music
sect1.para: Dal-Kon has a rich musical tradition. This tradition is displayed in part in popular songs and in Shinto ritual and chant as well as the court music and dances

Music is not a separable element from any other components of a performance. Music is almost always accompanied by some work, story, pantomime, dance, and/or acrobatics and all the musical styles are understood as music and some other component.

The dominant secular musical style of Dal-Kon is gigaku or Kure-gaku . This is the style of music for the popular dances and pantomimes of Ricefield workers and other manual workers. Later, however, it has risen to become the lowest form of official music
Sangaku is the most active and exciting of the musics-interspersed between songs were acrobatics and energetic pantomimes. It arose from the original Sohei traditions of battle theater and song.

Shinto chant is chanting performed largely in prayers, the norito , or "divine words." Shinto musical performance is exoteric, designed to be performed and comprehended by anyone with little musical training.
Perhaps the most permanent and complex musical culture developed in Dal-Kon is the gagaku, or court instrumental music.

In Dal-Kon, gagaku means "refined" (ga ) "music" (gaku ) and so is perfectly in line with the Dal-Kon Courts cultural value of miyabi , or "courtly refinement." Since the emphasis is on refinement or taste, gagaku is largely experienced as an elite or esoteric music, a "high culture" music in contrast to other Dal-Kon musical traditions. Like other Dal-Kon musical traditions, gagaku is not "music alone" but rather music and dance or pantomime. The entire gagaku experience, from the music to the singing to the story to the dance is regarded as refined and elegant. It's important to understand that gagaku is not a distinct musical classification but is a category that subsumes several musical and performance genres. It is largely a distinction between music for refined, courtly tastes, and all other types of music.
The daily life of the Dal-Kon imperial court is filled with gagaku. All ceremonies, weddings, funerals, affairs of state, all are accompanied by the musical style most appropriate to the occasion.

Dal-Kon musical theory is based on the eight categories of sound : metal (bells), stone (stone chimes), earth (ocarina), leather (drums), silk (stringed instruments), wood (double reed wind instruments), gourd (sho, or mouth organ), and bamboo (flute).

Dal-Kon think of musical instruments as two distinct categories: percussion and all others. The instruments associated with gagaku are stringed instruments and wind instruments similar to the flute; the percussion instruments, however, are seen as lesser instruments.

Principle among the stringed instruments is the biwa, which, like so much else in Dal-Kon music culture, is imported from Rhelania. It is not only the most important instrument in court orchestras, the biwa is also a work of fine art as the biis that are used are among the finest crafted works of the Dal-Kon instruments.

The biwa is a four-stringed instrument. In gagaku orchestras it is common but tends to be used for the grunt work-the bulk of the musical work is done by the six- stringed wagon and the thirteen- stringed koto with their more complex and rich modes.

Among the wind instruments, the principle instruments are the shakuhachi, a bamboo flute, and the sho , a mouth organ built of seventeen bamboo pipes arranged in a circle. The shakuhachi flute is played with the flute dangling down in front of the performer;

Percussion is a standard part of Dal-Kon ensemble music. Three of the tonal categories in Dal-Kon musical theory are taken up by percussion: metal, stone, and leather. The Dal-Kon employed three percussion instruments: a side drum (kakko ), a bronze gong (shoko ), and a large, hanging drum struck by two large, heavy drumsticks (taiko ). As with most percussion, taiko music is very close to the origins of music in the movement of the body and a real experience requires seeing as well as hearing the performance. Taiko performance is based on the modulation between the "female" (left hand) and "male" (right hand) strokes of the drumsticks-the female stroke is always soft and the male is always a strong stroke. The modulation between soft and strong is the primary component of taiko performance. In addition to court music, percussion is a vital part of Shinto ceremonies and processions. The instruments and rhythms are different than court music, but Shinto life and ceremony is filled with percussive richness.

chapter.title: Clothing and Color
chapter.para: Love of colour resurfaces again and again throughout Dal-Konese costume history. The colours have relationships with Dal-Kon philosophy and superstition. Blue-green represents wood, Spring, and the East. Red stands for fire, Summer, and the South. White is for Autumn, Metal, and the West. The North aligns with Winter, Water, and Black. And Yellow is the Center and Earth.
The Dal-Kon practice the use of distinction by colour. Luckily for most the distinctions are combinations of clothing type and color rather than color alone.

Clothing and color among the court and the Inner Clans are more ornate than among the Outer Clans. In fact it can be said that there are two distinct clothing cultures among the Dal-Kon. The Court or Inner Clan Culture and the Outer Clan culture.

In the Dal-Kon Court colours are strict indicators of rank. In Dal-Kon, courtiers take the native appreciation of colour and its subtlety to a higher level. Although men's court clothing is regulated by rank, a man in casual dress showed his refinement and sensitivity by pairing colours according to the season, the occasion, or his mood. And if Dal-Kon men excel at this practice, Dal-Kon women are masters. Less restricted by rank colours than men, a Dal-Kon lady can make or break her reputation with her choice of colours to wear in combination. Indeed, the mistress of the household (that is, the principle wife) is responsible for all the dyeing that goes on. The Dyers Tomo associated with a Han is beholden and reports to the ranking woman of the Han. It is no surprize that the Imperial post of Mikushige-dono, Mistress of the Wardrobe, is often held by the oldest Imperial concubine.
The ranking colours had to be produced precisely using the correct materials. These colours are purple, blue, red, yellow, white and black.

In the Dal-Kon court there are several official clothing colours in addition to white. These colors, when combined, with specific types of court costume are used to denote ranking within the court. Each color is produced with dyestuffs referenced in the Dal-Kon Classics. Yellow is made from gardenia hulls and bark of the Amur cork tree. Purple is from Murasaki roots. Red is from madder root. Blue-green is from indigo overdyed with yellow for green. Black is produced from the shell of the Abalone.
The Imperial Household has authorized an official Dyers Tomo or Naisenshi for the official colors.

Murasaki is native to Dal-Kon. In some periods this beautiful but non-lightfast purple was restricted to Imperial ladies only. In addition to its ephemerality, a careful process of premordanting had to be followed in order to produce the correct shade. Often called simply iro ("colour" in Dal-Kon), there is no doubt that it is THE colour of the Court.

Suo is imported from Rhelania as dried wood chips from the Suo or Sappanwood tree. This redwood is of the same species as the basilwood and produces the same dyestuff. Again, its lack of lightfastness makes this colour desirable. By manipulating the dyebath by the addition of wood ash water of vinegar, the imperial dyers can produce everything from deep eggplant to lavender and maroon to ox-blood red.

Benibana or safflower is probably the most fleeting of all the dyes. Like murasaki, benibana is also a restricted dye, though courtiers favoured by the Emperor were often given special permission to wear it. Dyeing with safflower requires careful manipulation of the acid dyebath. Anyone can produce yellow from the petals. Orange requires more skill. But pink ( kurenai) is the restricted colour.
The colour combinations (called kasane no irome in Dal-Kon) are stylised and many combinations have a name. Late Dal-Kon period texts such as Masasuke's "Notes on Costume" catalog these outfits.

Austerity is the hallmark of the Outer Clans. Fashion reflects this rebellion against the perceived decadence of the Dal-Kon court. Instead of many layered silk garments, Outer Clan ladies wear "underwear." White kosode and red hakama, which on the Dal-Kon Inner Clan noblewoman is rarely seen, became the utilitarian garb of the Outer Clan. There is strong significance in the names of the main garment - ko-sode (small sleeve) as opposed to hiro-sode (wide sleeve) or o-sode (big sleeve) as the Dal-Kon Inner Clan layers are sometimes called. There is even an anecdote that relates how an Outer Clan Daimyo chopped off his own brother's big sleeves with a sword because he believed him to be reverting to courtly decadence.

epigraph.attribution: Takeda Toshiro, founder of Clan Takeda, in his clan
epigraph.para: I was flinging drops of sweat when I completed the dance. I felt full of power; like a glowing lump of iron fresh from the forge. All the rage had accumulated in the middle. This was a imperial rage, a righteous wrath. At the center of my mind , wreathed in fire, was the image of the Emishi general. There lay the deepest inner rage, radiating fury: Emishi, through all these years, true source of these atrocities.

I stripped off my inner robe. I was vageuly aware of soldiers that had gathered to sit on hay bales and watch. I drew my Swords with a hard strike-draw combination and saluted the air with a flourish of edges. In that air hung the face of an Emishi. An Emishi general of great skill. Yes, clever man, with his priests behind him.

I began the Bladestorm. I was tired and that drove me at an even greater pace than my teacher ever used - which was foolish. The swords whined in the air with a sound I had never heard from them before, the droning whine of the legendary Bladestorm of my teacher's own teachers. Bladestorm was for the suicidal idiot whirling in a light footed fight across the unstable scree of a cliff, over loose rocks, among multiple enemies. An error in timing or breath control with the whirling blades caused the dancer to slash himself. Such was the concentration required that a dancer did not bleed from cuts. There stories of dancers bowshot, gutted and gashed and never noticing it, never stopping, until the end of the dance - when they dropped dead over their shredded victims.

The hilts of the swords slapped my hands lightly, spun and reversed hands, and rose to salute the air, and I was done. I stood there blinking a moment before I could break myself from the rhythm. My breath came in great regular heaves. The air felt to thick for breathing. Somehow my body, arrogant in the sight of so many eyes, pulled itself upright. I sheathed my blades and reached for a rag to wipe the sweat from my shoulders. To me, the sound of my breathing was deafening. My nephew Higaru reached forth a hand with a flask of sake spiked water. I had just touched it to my lips when stirrings at the edge of the camp announced what we had waited for. The Emishi marched to meet us.

As I prepared my armor and lost myself in the chatter of a camp preparing to march, I wondered whether I had become a great master or an even greater fool. The only answer to hand was that I didn't know. It was the barest beginnings of wisdom.

Koyasan is a mountaintop basin resting over 2400 feet above sea level and measuring 2 miles east to west, 1.5 miles north to south. The basin is surrounded by two concentric rims of hills, each of which is comprised of eight peaks. The basin thus resembles the shape of an unfolding lotus flower. The marvellously purplish mists that drape the sacred peaks at dawn and dusk present a suitably sublime figure
